data.Title: Google June 2024 Spam Update Rolling Out
data.Description: Google has begun rolling out its June 2024 spam update, which is expected to take about a week to complete. This update is considered a "normal, broad spam update" and is not related to the 'site reputation abuse' enforcement or link spam.

data.Title: Google Search Indexing Issue Resolved
data.Description: Google has addressed an indexing issue that was preventing new content from being indexed and served. The issue was affecting major websites and was acknowledged by Google on its Search Status dashboard.

data.Title: Google AI Overviews Appearing Less Frequently
data.Description: Google's AI Overviews are appearing less frequently in search results, now showing up for an average of 7-9% of queries. Additionally, Reddit is no longer among the top 10 most cited domains in these overviews.

data.Title: Google Universal Analytics Data Deletion on July 1st
data.Description: Users will lose access to Universal Analytics data and interface on July 1st. After this date, all Universal Analytics data will be permanently deleted.

data.Title: Google Search Image Thumbnails Disappearing Due to Quality Issues
data.Description: Google may be removing image thumbnails from search result snippets due to quality issues with the website, not technical issues. This was confirmed by John Mueller from Google.

data.Title: Local Service Ads Coming to Google Maps
data.Description: Google is bringing Local Service Ads to Google Maps, starting with iOS devices. There is currently no option to opt out of this feature without disabling Local Service Ads entirely.

data.Title: Perplexity CEO Responds to Plagiarism Allegations
data.Description: Perplexity CEO Aravind Srinivas addressed allegations of plagiarism, stating that the company does not ignore robots.txt but relies on a third-party for web crawling and indexing.

data.Title: Apple Delays Features in EU Citing DMA Concerns
data.Description: Apple will withhold the release of Apple Intelligence, iPhone Mirroring, and other features in the EU this year. The company cites concerns about the DMA's interoperability requirements, claiming they would force Apple to "downgrade the security of its products and services."
